abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Individuals who carry <jats:italic>BRCA1</jats:italic> or <jats:italic>BRCA2</jats:italic> pathogenic variants are recommended to have extensive cancer prevention screening and risk-reducing surgeries. Uptake of these recommendations is variable, and there remains room for improvement in the risk management of <jats:italic>BRCA</jats:italic> carriers. This paper explores female <jats:italic>BRCA</jats:italic> carriers’ experiences with the current model of care and their perspectives on (and interest in) an inherited cancer registry. Findings can inform the development of a dedicated high-risk screening and management program for these patients. Quantitative and qualitative data were gathered through a provincial descriptive survey and semi-structured qualitative interviews to assess <jats:italic>BRCA</jats:italic> carriers’ opinions toward risk management services in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), Canada. Survey (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 69) and interview data (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 15) revealed continuity and coordination challenges with the current system of care of high-risk individuals. Respondents suggested an inherited cancer registry would help identify high-risk individuals and provide a centralized system of risk management for identified carriers. Respondents identified concerns about the privacy of their registry data, including who could access it. Findings suggest <jats:italic>BRCA</jats:italic> carriers see great value in an inherited cancer registry. Specifically, participants noted it could provide a centralized system to help improve the coordination of burdensome, life-long risk management. Important patient concerns about protecting their privacy and their health data confidentiality must be addressed in patient and public information and informed consent documents about a registry.</jats:p>

assertion.value: Ethics approval was granted from the provincial Health Research Ethics Board in St. John’s, NL, Canada (Ref # 2018.221). All procedures followed were in accordance with the ethical standards of the responsible committee on human experimentation (institutional and national) and with the Helsinki Declaration of 1975, as revised in 2000. Informed consent was obtained from all patients for being included in the study.

assertion.value: Informed consent was obtained from all interview respondents at the beginning of the interview. Survey consent was implied if respondents submitted a survey.
